cases.case_summary: A previously healthy 22-year-old woman presented with severe headache, fever, respiratory failure, neurological changes, thrombocytopenia, and imaging consistent with infarcts and hemorrhage.

differential_diagnosis.reasoning: Clinical features match disseminated fungal infection causing septic emboli, infarcts, pulmonary lesions, and neurological deterioration.
Systemic embolization and cardiac murmur indicate possible endocarditis; negative cultures limit confidence.
Systemic involvement fits vasculitis but lacks supportive serology.
Consistent systemic symptoms but lacks rash and epidemiological exposure.
Negative ANA and absence of lupus history decrease likelihood significantly.

cases.case_summary: 54-year-old male athlete with progressive exertional dyspnea, restrictive cardiac physiology, biatrial enlargement, and discordant ECG findings.

differential_diagnosis.reasoning: Typical infiltrative pattern with restrictive physiology, low-voltage ECG despite hypertrophy.
Classic phenotype of hypertrophy, but negative genetic findings limit confidence.
Clinical lack of extracardiac sarcoidosis reduces likelihood.
Absence of typical systemic features and negative genetic testing makes unlikely.
Severity and progression inconsistent with benign athletic adaptation.

cases.case_summary: A 73-year-old man presented with chronic recurrent fever, hepatosplenic granulomatous lesions, splenomegaly, cytopenias, and negative infectious workup.

differential_diagnosis.reasoning: Recurrent infections, granulomas, progressive cytopenias strongly suggest underlying immunodeficiency.
Granulomatous infections match CGD phenotype, though typically earlier onset.
Absence of pulmonary involvement and lymphadenopathy makes this less likely.
Consistent lesions but negative testing reduces confidence.
Repeated negative TB tests significantly lower suspicion.

cases.case_summary: 30-year-old postpartum woman presented with fever, progressive abdominal pain, rapidly ulcerating skin lesions, and systemic inflammatory syndrome.

differential_diagnosis.diagnosis: Pyoderma Gangrenosum associated with Crohn’s Disease
differential_diagnosis.reasoning: Pathergy, rapidly progressive neutrophilic ulcers, and family history of Crohn’s strongly support this diagnosis.
Rapid onset neutrophilic skin lesions consistent, but deep ulceration uncommon.
Repeated sterile cultures strongly oppose infectious etiology.
Lack of clear thrombotic events or antiphospholipid antibodies.
Absence of classic mucocutaneous ulcers and other characteristic manifestations.

cases.final_diagnosis: Pyoderma Gangrenosum associated with underlying Crohn’s Disease
